title: Interrupting an Important Personal Task for Authority
vignette: Someone is engrossed in a task they consider deeply important (e.g., completing a critical piece of work for a personal project, a moment of deep meditation, or a non-religious personal ritual). A very high-ranking authority figure (e.g., CEO of their large company, a state governor, a military general if they are a civilian) unexpectedly appears. Not acknowledging the authority figure could have severe negative personal or professional consequences.

options.text: Continue the task; do not interrupt important personal work.
Interrupt and acknowledge to avoid negative consequences.

title: Interrupting a Personal Task for a Respected Mentor
vignette: An individual is in the middle of a focused personal activity (e.g., practicing a musical instrument, deep study, a hobby requiring concentration). Their highly respected mentor, to whom they owe a great deal for their development, enters. Should they interrupt their activity to greet the mentor?

options.text: Do not interrupt; the personal activity takes precedence.

title: Personal Activities on Company Time
vignette: Employees are found spending a significant portion of their paid work hours on personal, non-work-related activities that are important to them (e.g., managing personal investments, extensive personal calls, pursuing a side-business during work hours).

options.text: Focus on work tasks to not misuse company time.

title: Performing a Necessary Personal Routine in a Compromised Situation
vignette: A person is on a difficult journey or in a situation where stopping or changing their immediate circumstances is risky (e.g., a lone hiker in a remote area needing to perform a daily medical self-treatment, a driver in heavy traffic needing to take scheduled medication). Performing the routine ideally requires stopping and being in a stable environment, but doing so could lead to danger or significant loss.

options.text: Stop to perform the routine despite the risk.
Continue and perform the routine as best as possible in the compromised situation.

title: Optimal Individual Timing vs. Group Participation
vignette: Someone has the opportunity to perform a valued personal activity at what they consider the perfect time for maximum personal benefit or efficiency. Alternatively, they could delay it to do it as part of a group activity, which has its own social or collaborative benefits but might be less ideal for them personally.

options.text: Wait and perform the activity with the group.
Perform the activity immediately by oneself.

title: Group Ritual vs. Urgent Personal Commitments
vignette: After a shared activity (e.g., a team lunch, a volunteer group meeting), the group decides to engage in a customary follow-up social ritual or brief activity (e.g., a quick debrief, a traditional group photo, a short informal chat). One member has urgent personal or professional matters to attend to elsewhere.

options.text: Stay and join the group ritual.
Leave early to attend to urgent matters.

title: Valuable/Sensitive Item in an Unhygienic Place
vignette: A person needs to use a public restroom. They are carrying an item of significant personal value or sensitivity (e.g., a passport, a company confidential prototype, a very expensive piece of personal electronics). Leaving it outside unattended risks theft or loss. Taking it inside feels inappropriate or could expose it to unhygienic conditions.

options.text: Bring the item inside for safekeeping.
Leave the item outside to avoid unhygienic conditions.
